Award.AwardTitle: The 10th William Rowan Hamilton Geometry and Topology Workshop, August 26 - 30, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 10th William Rowan Hamilton Geometry and Topology Workshop is a five-day, directed workshop on Homology and Geometry, to be held at the Hamilton Mathematical Institute (HMI) in Dublin, Ireland, August 26-30, 2014. The goal of the William Rowan Hamilton Geometry and Topology Workshop is to investigate common themes and techniques among significant areas of current research in geometry and topology and to support junior researchers interested in these areas. The workshop will bring together leading researchers in geometry and topology with graduates students and junior researchers who have a special interest in problems related to low-dimensional geometry, topology and geometric group theory, to investigate questions at the forefront of research in these areas. The confluence of expertise from different areas will result in new collaborative projects, and in broadening the research horizons of the participants.


The workshop will consist of a two-day mini-course for graduate students and junior researchers, followed by a three day lecture series. The purpose of the workshop is to investigate common themes and techniques among significant areas of current research in geometry and topology. Major topics of this year's workshop include, the behavior of homology invariants under coverings, minimal genus representatives of 4-manifold homology classes, and homological properties of manifolds with left-orderable fundamental groups.

The workshop website is located at http://www.hamilton.tcd.ie/events/gt/gt2014.htm

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award helped to fund the 10th annual William Rowan Hamilton Workshop in Geometry and Topology, titled “Homological invariants and low dimensional topology”. It which was a five-day directed workshop held at the Hamilton Mathematical Institute (HMI) in Dublin, Ireland,  August 26–30, 2014. 

The workshop consisted of a two-day mini-course August 26-27, which included survey lectures by Jacob Rasmussen (Cambridge) and Liam Watson (Glasgow), followed by a 3-day lecture series August 28 - 30 with 14 speakers.  The topic of the workshop was very broad, and the mini course helped to orient those attendees (especially graduate students and junior researchers) who lacked familiarity with the “L-space conjecture”, which was a major focus of the workshop. The lecture series then gave researchers at the forefront of the field an opportunity to disseminate their recent advances and to propose new directions of research.

Perhaps the greatest success of the 2014 workshop was that it brought together researchers from very different fields (e.g. Heegaard—Floer homology, hyperbolic geometry and higher Teichmuller—Thurston theory), and yet managed to have a coherent direction. The talks were generally all comprehensible to nonexperts, and there were many `across the aisle’ conversations.  A primary goal of the workshop was to facilitate the formation of new collaborations between the different research teams, as well as support ongoing collaborations, and we feel this goal was certainly attained.

The organizers of the 2014 workshop were:

 Javier Aramayona, National University of Ireland, Galway

Hyperbolic geometry, geometric group theory

John Baldwin, Boston College,  Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA

  Low-dimensional geometry and topology

Ian Biringer, Boston College,  Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA

  Hyperbolic geometry

Noel Brady, University of Oklahoma, Norman, Oklahoma, USA

Geometric group theory, low-dimensional topology

Martin Bridgeman, Boston College,  Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA

Hyperbolic geometry, geometric analysis, low-dimensional topology

Martin Bridson, Oxford, England

Geometric group theory, low-dimensional topology, metric spaces of non- positive curvature

Josh Greene, Boston College,  Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA

Low-dimensional topology

Robert Meyerhoff, Boston College,  Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA

Topology, geometry of low-dimensional manifolds

Tom Brady, Dublin City University

Geometric group theory

Vladimir Dotsenko, Trinity College Dublin

Homological and homotopical algebra, combinatorics, representation theory

Brendan Guilfoyle, Tralee institute of Technology

Differential geometry, mathematical physics

There were 76 participants in total, including 43 graduate students and 9 postdocs.
